name: transport, freight, lorry with refrigeration machine, 3.5-7.5 ton, EURO6, R134a refrigerant, freezing | transport, freight, lorry with refrigeration machine, 3.5-7.5 ton, EURO6, R134a refrigerant, freezing | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/14067/documentation

This dataset represents transport of goods in lorry with atmosphere controlled (temperature, humidity, etc.) storage space set up for freezing.;While the majority of the atmosphere controlled (cold chain, refrigerated transport) road transportation is conducted with truck with semi-trailer in the cities this goods is often transported by smaller rigid trucks with refrigeration machine. 

This activity starts with input of fuel, road and vehicle infrastructure including refrigeration machine. It includes also exhaust and non-exhaust emissions.

This datasets combines the transport of 1 ton of goods over 1km by a lorry with refrigeration machine. The goods themselves are not included.
category: H:Transportation and storage/49:Land transport and transport via pipelines/492:Other land transport/4923:Freight transport by road

processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The construction of the refrigeration machine does not change very much in time. What might be changing is the 1) type of refrigerant, 2) energy consumption - efficiency and 3) leakage of the refrigerant. ;The datasets on transport, freight, lorry with refrigeration machine present in the ecoinvent database represent several scenarios with different type of refrigerant, energy consumption and leakage of the refrigerant.. ;The technology level is set reflecting the EURO classification, i.e. EURO3 is the oldest technology and EURO6 the newest. The R134a refrigerant is currently most widely used refrigerant, while the carbon dioxide, liquid is the newer more “environmentally friendly” solution. Therefore all the lorries using the carbon dioxide, liquid as refrigerant have higher level of technology than those using the R134a as refrigerant.

exchanges.description: Estimated value. Fuel dependant emissions - heavy metal in fuel. Estimated using the underlying assumption that 0.2% of the emitted Cr is emitted as Cr(IV). Fuel dependant emissions - heavy metal in fuel. Literature value for Cr. EMEP/EEA (2013) Tab. 3-100.

Literature value. The NMVOC split is provided by the EMEP/EEA (2013) guidebook. All elementary NMVOC exchanges available in the ecoinvent database and quantified in the EMEP/EEA guidebook are provided. Total NMVOC's derived from HBEFA database (Keller, 2010)..

Literature value. The NMVOC split is provided by the EMEP/EEA (2013) guidebook. All elementary NMVOC exchanges available in the ecoinvent database and quantified in the EMEP/EEA guidebook are provided. Total NMVOC's derived from HBEFA database (Keller, 2010)..

Calculated value based demand factors and underlying assumptions for European road transport services. Values are based on total vkm of all road transport services (RER) and the relative shares of each specific form (e.g. 3.5-7.5t lorry). The value per tkm is then based on the average load factor (see Activity Description). Transport performance data is derived from TREMOVE (2009).

Literature value. The NMVOC split is provided by the EMEP/EEA (2013) guidebook. All elementary NMVOC exchanges available in the ecoinvent database and quantified in the EMEP/EEA guidebook are provided. Total NMVOC's derived from HBEFA database (Keller, 2010)..

Road freight specific non-exhaust emissions.

This dataset and the emission factors within it relate to 1kg of tyre wear. In order to use the treatment of non-exhaust emissions in a transport dataset the quantity of emissions per km must be calculated. Non-exhaust emissions are considered to be linearly scalable to gross vehicle weight (GVW). For tyre wear emissions from lorries the specific quantity is 8.055E-8 kg/kg GVW*km. 

The GVW of the 3.5-7.5t lorries using an average load factor is 4984kg.

The value calculated must then be devided by the average load to give the non-exhaust emissions per tkm.

exchanges.description: Literature value. Derived from HBEFA database (Keller, 2010) and emissions inventory guidebook (EMEP/EEA, 2013). Unspecified NMVOC's represent NMVOC's for which no elementary exchange exists in the ecoinvent database. Total NMVOC's are given by the HBEFA database with the split being provided by the EMEP/EEA (2013) guidebook.

Literature value. The NMVOC split is provided by the EMEP/EEA (2013) guidebook. All elementary NMVOC exchanges available in the ecoinvent database and quantified in the EMEP/EEA guidebook are provided. Total NMVOC's derived from HBEFA database (Keller, 2010)..
Calculated value based on lifetime vkm (540 000 for all lorry sizes) and average load factors (see Activity Description).

Non-exhaust emissions are considered to be linearly scalable to gross vehicle weight (GVW). For road wear emissions due to lorries the specific quantity is 7.0E-9 kg/kg GVW*km.

The value calculated must then be devided by the average load to give the non-exhaust emissions per tkm.
